Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Adjuvant αDC1 Vaccination with Chemokine Modulation after CRS/HIPEC

Participants.evidence: enrolled patients with appendiceal cancer, colorectal cancer, or peritoneal mesothelioma at the University of Pittsburgh. Eligibility included histologically proven peritoneal metastases and the ability to undergo plasmapheresis.

Intervention.evidence: Participants received intranodal and intradermal injections of autologous tumor-loaded αDC1 vaccine and CKM, consisting of celecoxib, interferon (IFN)-α, and rintatolimod.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the safety and efficacy of adjuvant αDC1 vaccination with chemokine modulation (CKM) following cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS/HIPEC).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was progression-free survival (PFS), measured over a median follow-up period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty-six patients were analysed, with 24 appendiceal, 20 colorectal, and 2 mesothelioma cases.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Median PFS for appendiceal cancer was 50.4, 34.2, and 8.9 months for grades 1, 2, and 3, respectively, and 20.5 and 8.9 months for moderately and poorly differentiated colorectal tumors.

Harms.evidence: The regimen was well tolerated, with common adverse events being mild flu-like symptoms. Six patients experienced grades 3–5 adverse events, including lymphocyte count decrease and gastrointestinal bleed.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under NCT02151448.

Funding.evidence: Funding was provided by institutional sources.
